Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I:Ground-Loop Heat Exchanger Solution for Low Cost Ground-Source Heat Pumps
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is that it will significantly lower the initial cost of residential and commercial ground-source heat pump (GSHP) systems, while expanding the existing market through broadening GSHP applicability. This project will demonstrate the feasibility and performance under real-world conditions of a novel in-ground heat exchanger that is both inexpensive and easy to install, even on space-constrained lots, with little landscape disruption. The technology will lead to increased adoption of energy-efficient heating/ventilation/air conditioning (HVAC) technology, increasing the “electrification” of the energy economy and reducing air polluting emissions. These GSHP systems will impact the national market of heating and cooling systems, with potential annual energy savings of over 6.4 quadrillion BTUs, end-user savings of $77. B in annual energy costs, and reduced peak electricity demand by 144 GW.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to further develop a technology addressing the applicability, desirability and cost-competitiveness of GSHP systems. The chief technical objective of the project is to optimize system components and architectures by increasing fundamental understanding of in-ground heat exchanger performance and installation methods through digital and physical prototyping across a range of real-world conditions. A second technical objective is to improve fundamental understanding of the energy storage capability of the technology and how it can be leveraged through operational cycling to further increase the performance-cost ratio. Studies of physical prototyping, installation and thermal properties will be conducted, in addition to computational fluid dynamic (CFD) simulations. The primary goals are to demonstrate significant benefits in installed performance-to-cost and an installation time of under 8 hours for a typical residential 3-ton system, compared to the current state-of-the-art of 16 hours.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broader impact from the commercialization of the technology that was the subject of the research performed as part of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to significantly lower the initial cost of residential and commercial ground-source heat pump (GSHP) systems while also expanding the market for such systems by broadening GSHP applicability. This project has demonstrated the feasibility and performance under real-world conditions of a novel in-ground heat exchanger that is both inexpensive and easy to install, even on space-constrained lots, with little landscape disruption. The technology will lead to increased adoption of energy-efficient heating/ventilation/air conditioning (HVAC) technology, increasing the electrification of the energy economy and reducing air polluting emissions. GSHP systems enabled by the studied in-ground heat exchanger technology will impact the national market of heating and cooling systems, with potential annual energy savings of over 6.4 quadrillion BTUs, end-user savings of $77. B in annual energy costs, and reduced peak electricity demand by 144 GW.

This SBIR Phase I project further developed a technology addressing the applicability, desirability and cost-competitiveness of GSHP systems. The chief technical objectives achieved during this project were the proof of concept and the optimization of system components and architectures with the performance-to-cost ratio as the objective function to be maximized. Through increasing our fundamental understanding of the phenomenon at work, and by developing tools that are able to accurately predict system performance and costs across a range of real-world conditions, we have achieved a performance-to-cost ratio of more than double that of current state-of-the-art technologies. A second technical objective was to improve the fundamental understanding of how geology, climate and geophysical data impact the design and performance of our systems for our target markets. Studies of physical prototyping, installation and thermal properties have been successfully conducted, in addition to computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations. The primary goals of doubling performance-to-cost ratio and reducing lead times to under 3 days for a typical residential HVAC  system have been achieved.
